intro: Cochlidium graminoides, commonly known as the grassy bladderwort, is a small aquatic plant belonging to the family Lentibacillaceae. It is characterized by its delicate, floating leaves and specialized bladders used for capturing small aquatic organisms. The plant thrives in still or slow-moving freshwater environments, such as ponds and ditches. Its morphology includes slender stems and tiny, translucent bladders that aid in nutrient absorption. Cochlidium graminoides plays a role in aquatic ecosystems by contributing to the food web and maintaining water quality.
